news_summary: Today's news highlights advancements in nuclear science, innovative research approaches, and strong advocacy supporting the future of US scientists.
news_summary_fr: Les nouvelles d'aujourd'hui mettent en lumière les avancées dans le domaine de la science nucléaire, les approches de recherche novatrices et la forte mobilisation en faveur de l'avenir des scientifiques américains.
news_summary_es: Las noticias de hoy destacan los avances de la ciencia nuclear, los enfoques innovadores de la investigación y la firme defensa del futuro de los científicos estadounidenses.

articles.title: How I’m advocating in Congress for the next generation of US scientists
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 22 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01999-9Adriana Bankston’s year-long policy fellowship allows her to fight for science and scientists at a crucial time.
articles.content:
Adriana Bankston at Capitol Hill in Washington DC.Credit: Adriana Bankston

In September 2024, two months before the US presidential election returned Donald Trump to power for a second term, I secured a congressional fellowship to work for Bill Foster, a former physicist who was elected to the House of Representatives as a Democrat for an Illinois district.

The year-long science and technology policy fellowship, based at the US Congress in Washington DC, allows scientists and engineers to learn about and contribute to national policymaking. It is sponsored by the American Society of Gene & Cell Therapy as part of the Science and Technology Policy Fellowships programme of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

On a typical day, I work on science and research policy, and science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education, among other topics. This includes defending scientific research and the STEM pipeline — through letters, speeches and legislation — attending meetings with Foster’s constituents, collaborating with other congressional offices that share these interests, and contributing to the advancement of US science at a national level.

Action on salaries

My path into research policy dates back almost a decade, beginning in 2016, when, after a postdoctoral position at the University of Louisville in Kentucky, I joined the non-profit organization Future of Research, based in Pittsfield, Massachusetts.

Our research into postdoc salaries revealed that many fell below US$45,000 a year, although a federal labour law mandated a minimum of $47,476. Postdoctoral salaries increased as a result of our work.

More roles in science advocacy followed, including as a fellow with the Society for Neuroscience, and principal legislative analyst with the University of California’s Office of Federal Governmental Relations, both in Washington DC.

Both roles involved lobbying Congress to increase federal funding for scientific research. I then moved on to helping universities and scientific organizations engage with Congress on science issues, and enabling graduate students and postdoctoral researchers to discuss their work with members of Congress.

Favourite projects

In my current role, four favourite projects spring to mind. The first was reintroducing a resolution to designate 14 March as National Pi Day, which is an opportunity to highlight and recognize the need for investments in mathematics and science education, and getting students interested in STEM subjects.

The second was the Keep STEM Talent Act, which would enable international STEM students to contribute to the workforce and our economy by giving them permanent-resident status.

The third was drafting a speech by Foster from the floor of the House of Representatives, expressing concern with the Trump administration’s cut to the Graduate Research Fellowship Program of the National Science Foundation (NSF). The reduction in funding is preventing outstanding graduate students from pursuing research-based master’s or doctoral degrees in STEM fields.

And finally, I enjoyed writing research talking points for the National Lab Research SLAM, which showcases the contributions to the innovation ecosystem of early-career scientists at the national laboratories — defined as any government-operated or sponsored laboratory.

This year is the 75th anniversary of the NSF. As part of Foster’s team, I contributed to multiple projects defending science funding and federal agencies, and Foster gave a speech from the floor during a Special Order Hour — time set aside for speeches or debates that are not part of the ordinary legislative agenda — which was focused on standing up for science. The speech highlighted how Trump’s proposed budget cuts at the NSF and other science agencies are impairing US competitiveness and the development of the STEM workforce. Along with other members of Congress, Foster introduced a resolution commemorating the NSF’s science and engineering accomplishments over the past 75 years. Our team also initiated and helped to coordinate letters from Congress to the Trump administration expressing concern over the firing of 168 NSF workers, and over the administration’s directive to freeze all NSF grant funding.

Gratification and heartbreak

This has been the most gratifying year of my career so far.

Although I sometimes am heartbroken by what is happening to scientific research in this country, I increasingly find myself encouraged by the resilience of this community to continue fighting for what matters. Being part of this cause is extremely rewarding.

I have heard from scientists, including early-career trainees, about the impacts of cuts to federal science funding. Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who are just starting out describe feeling uncertain. And those halfway through or close to finishing their degrees are struggling to find the funds to continue their work, and have shared their worries about academic job prospects.

I encourage US scientists to continue talking to Congress, especially to members who care about these issues and have the power to change things. If a scientist is also a constituent of that member of Congress, the connection can go a long way, because members are supposed to listen and work to address the issues. And by participating in national rallies or local demonstrations, researchers can make the case for the importance of science for their communities and the country’s future.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights advocacy for the next generation of US scientists through a policy fellowship, which supports science and scientists at a crucial time. This represents positive government policy efforts and individual achievements that inspire others.
articles.personality_title: Fighting for future US scientists on Capitol Hill
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In 2024, as the US prepared for a presidential election, Adriana Bankston, a dedicated scientist, earned a special fellowship. This program places scientists inside Congress to help shape better science policies.

**What happened**
Adriana began working with Bill Foster, a former physicist turned congressman from Illinois. Through this year-long fellowship, she uses her scientific knowledge to influence decisions in Washington, supporting scientists and technology development.

**Impact**
This fellowship bridges science and government, ensuring lawmakers understand scientific challenges and opportunities. Adriana's work helps create policies that boost research and protect the interests of future scientists.

**What's next step**
After her fellowship, Adriana aims to keep advocating for science, inspiring others to join efforts that make science a priority in government. Continued support for such fellowships can strengthen science policy nationwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By bringing scientists directly into Congress, programs like Adriana’s fellowship help shape a brighter future for US science and innovation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Soutenir les futurs scientifiques américains au Capitole
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
En 2024, alors que les États-Unis se préparaient à une élection présidentielle, Adriana Bankston, une scientifique engagée, a obtenu une bourse spéciale. Ce programme place des scientifiques au sein du Congrès pour aider à créer de meilleures politiques scientifiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Adriana a commencé à travailler avec Bill Foster, un ancien physicien devenu député de l’Illinois. Grâce à cette bourse d’un an, elle utilise ses connaissances scientifiques pour influencer les décisions à Washington, soutenant les scientifiques et le développement technologique.

**Impact**
Cette bourse fait le lien entre science et gouvernement, garantissant que les législateurs comprennent les défis et les opportunités scientifiques. Le travail d’Adriana aide à créer des politiques qui favorisent la recherche et protègent les intérêts des futurs scientifiques.

**Prochaine étape**
Après sa bourse, Adriana souhaite continuer à défendre la science et inspirer d’autres personnes à s’engager pour que la science soit une priorité au gouvernement. Le soutien continu à ce type de bourses peut renforcer la politique scientifique à l’échelle nationale.

**Une phrase clé**
En intégrant directement les scientifiques au Congrès, des programmes comme celui d’Adriana contribuent à façonner un avenir meilleur pour la science et l’innovation aux États-Unis.
articles.personality_title_es: Defendiendo a los futuros científicos de EE. UU. en el Capitolio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En 2024, mientras EE. UU. se preparaba para una elección presidencial, Adriana Bankston, una científica comprometida, obtuvo una beca especial. Este programa coloca a científicos dentro del Congreso para ayudar a crear mejores políticas científicas.

**Qué pasó**
Adriana comenzó a trabajar con Bill Foster, un exfísico convertido en congresista de Illinois. Con esta beca de un año, usa su conocimiento científico para influir en las decisiones en Washington, apoyando a los científicos y el desarrollo tecnológico.

**Impacto**
Esta beca une la ciencia y el gobierno, asegurando que los legisladores comprendan los retos y oportunidades científicas. El trabajo de Adriana ayuda a crear políticas que impulsan la investigación y protegen los intereses de los científicos futuros.

**Próximo paso**
Después de su beca, Adriana quiere seguir defendiendo la ciencia e inspirar a otros a unirse para que la ciencia sea una prioridad en el gobierno. El apoyo continuo a estas becas puede fortalecer la política científica en todo el país.

**Una frase clave**
Al llevar científicos directamente al Congreso, programas como la beca de Adriana ayudan a construir un futuro más brillante para la ciencia y la innovación en EE. UU.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a symbolic Capitol Hill dome made of intertwining DNA strands and mathematical symbols, glowing softly with natural blues and greens, surrounded by transparent silhouettes of diverse scientific tools like microscopes and test tubes gently reaching upward like hands, set against a calm sky at dawn to represent hope and advocacy for the future of US science and STEM education.

articles.title: Aluminium-20 shatters nuclear norms with explosive triple-proton breakup
articles.summary: Scientists have observed a brand-new and exotic atomic nucleus: aluminium-20. Unlike anything seen before, it decays through a stunning three-proton emission sequence, shedding light on nuclear behavior far beyond the limits of stability. This breakthrough, involving researchers from China and Germany, not only adds a new isotope to the nuclear chart but also hints at broken symmetry and unexpected quantum properties deep within matter.
articles.content:
Radioactive decay is a fundamental process in nature by which an unstable atomic nucleus loses energy by radiation. Studying nuclear decay modes is crucial for understanding properties of atomic nuclei. In particular, exotic decay modes like proton emission provide essential spectroscopic tools for probing the structure of nuclei far from the valley of stability -- the region containing stable nuclei on the nuclear chart.

In a study published in Physical Review Letters on July 10, physicists from the Institute of Modern Physics (IMP) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) and their collaborators have reported the first observation and spectroscopy of aluminium-20, a previously unknown and unstable isotope that decays via the rare process of three-proton emission.

"Aluminium-20 is the lightest aluminium isotope that has been discovered so far. Located beyond the proton drip line, it has seven fewer neutrons than the stable aluminum isotope," said Associate Prof. Xiaodong Xu from IMP, first author of the study.

Using an in-flight decay technique at the Fragment Separator of the GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research in Darmstadt, Germany, the researchers measured angular correlations of aluminium-20's decay products and discovered the previously unknown nucleus aluminium-20.

Through detailed analysis of angular correlations, the researchers found that the aluminium-20 ground state first decays by emitting one proton to the intermediate ground state of magnesium-19, followed by subsequent decay of magnesium-19 ground state via simultaneous two-proton emission. Aluminium-20 is the first observed three-proton emitter where its one-proton decay daughter nucleus is a two-proton radioactive nucleus.

The researchers also found that the decay energy of the aluminium-20 ground state is significantly smaller than the predictions inferred from the isospin symmetry, indicating a possible isospin symmetry breaking in aluminium-20 and its mirror partner neon-20.

This finding is supported by state-of-the-art theoretical calculations that predict that the spin-parity of the aluminium-20 ground state differs from the spin-parity of the neon-20 ground state.

"This study advances our understanding of the proton-emission phenomena, and provides insights into the structure and decay of nuclei beyond the proton drip line," said Xu.

To date, scientists have discovered over 3,300 nuclides, yet fewer than 300 are stable and exist naturally. The remainder are unstable nuclides that undergo radioactive decay. Common decay modes, such as α decay, β- decay, β+ decay, electron capture, γ radiation, and fission, were discovered by the mid-20th century.

Over the past several decades, owing to the tremendous development in nuclear physics experimental facilities and detection technologies, scientists discovered several exotic decay modes in the study of nuclei far from the stability, particularly in neutron-deficient nuclei.

In the 1970s, scientists discovered single-proton radioactivity, where nuclei decay by emitting a proton. After entering the 21st century, two-proton radioactivity was found in the decays of some extremely neutron-deficient nuclei. In recent years, even rarer decay phenomena such as three-, four-, and five-proton emission were observed.

This collaborative effort included contributions from IMP, GSI, Fudan University, and more than a dozen other institutions.

This work was supported by the National Key R&D Program of China, the CAS President's International Fellowship Initiative, and the National Natural Science Foundation of China, among others.
articles.reasoning: This news reports a significant scientific breakthrough in nuclear physics, revealing new atomic behavior and quantum properties. While it may not directly impact everyday life immediately, it advances human knowledge and could inspire further research and technological innovation.
articles.personality_title: Aluminium-20 breaks new ground with rare triple-proton decay
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists study how unstable atomic nuclei lose energy, a process called radioactive decay. This helps us understand the tiny world inside atoms. Sometimes, nuclei emit protons in rare ways that reveal surprising details about their structure.

**What happened**
Researchers from China and Germany discovered a completely new atomic nucleus called aluminium-20. Unlike anything seen before, aluminium-20 decays by releasing three protons in a row—a rare and exciting process. This triple-proton emission is a fresh glimpse into how atomic nuclei behave far beyond the usual stable forms.

**Impact**
This discovery adds a new isotope to the nuclear chart and suggests unusual quantum properties and broken symmetry deep within matter. These insights can deepen our understanding of nuclear physics and may lead to breakthroughs in technology and science as we explore the building blocks of the universe.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to study aluminium-20 further and look for other exotic nuclei with similar decay patterns. By exploring these rare behaviors, they hope to unlock more secrets about atomic structure and quantum physics.

**One-sentence takeaway**
The discovery of aluminium-20’s unique triple-proton decay opens a new window into the mysterious world of atomic nuclei and quantum behavior.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’aluminium-20 ouvre une nouvelle voie grâce à une désintégration rare à trois protons
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques étudient comment les noyaux atomiques instables perdent de l’énergie, un processus appelé désintégration radioactive. Cela nous aide à comprendre le monde minuscule à l’intérieur des atomes. Parfois, les noyaux émettent des protons de façon rare, révélant des détails surprenants sur leur structure.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs de Chine et d’Allemagne ont découvert un noyau atomique complètement nouveau appelé aluminium-20. Contrairement à tout ce qui a été vu auparavant, l’aluminium-20 se désintègre en libérant trois protons à la suite — un processus rare et passionnant. Cette émission triple de protons offre un nouveau regard sur le comportement des noyaux atomiques bien au-delà des formes stables habituelles.

**Impact**
Cette découverte ajoute un nouvel isotope à la carte nucléaire et suggère des propriétés quantiques inhabituelles ainsi qu’une symétrie rompue profondément dans la matière. Ces connaissances peuvent approfondir notre compréhension de la physique nucléaire et ouvrir la voie à des avancées scientifiques et technologiques en explorant les briques de l’univers.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d’étudier davantage l’aluminium-20 et de chercher d’autres noyaux exotiques avec des modes de désintégration similaires. En explorant ces comportements rares, ils espèrent percer davantage de secrets sur la structure atomique et la physique quantique.

**Une phrase clé**
La découverte de la désintégration unique à trois protons de l’aluminium-20 ouvre une nouvelle fenêtre sur le monde mystérieux des noyaux atomiques et du comportement quantique.
articles.personality_title_es: El aluminio-20 marca un nuevo camino con una rara desintegración triple de protones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos estudian cómo los núcleos atómicos inestables pierden energía, un proceso llamado desintegración radiactiva. Esto nos ayuda a entender el mundo diminuto dentro de los átomos. A veces, los núcleos emiten protones de formas raras que revelan detalles sorprendentes sobre su estructura.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores de China y Alemania descubrieron un núcleo atómico completamente nuevo llamado aluminio-20. A diferencia de todo lo visto antes, el aluminio-20 se desintegra liberando tres protones seguidos, un proceso raro y emocionante. Esta emisión triple de protones ofrece una nueva visión de cómo se comportan los núcleos atómicos mucho más allá de las formas estables comunes.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento añade un nuevo isótopo a la tabla nuclear y sugiere propiedades cuánticas inusuales y simetría rota en lo profundo de la materia. Estos conocimientos pueden profundizar nuestra comprensión de la física nuclear y abrir camino a avances científicos y tecnológicos explorando los bloques básicos del universo.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean estudiar más el aluminio-20 y buscar otros núcleos exóticos con patrones de desintegración similares. Al explorar estos comportamientos raros, esperan descubrir más secretos sobre la estructura atómica y la física cuántica.

**Conclusión en una frase**
El descubrimiento de la desintegración triple de protones única del aluminio-20 abre una nueva ventana al misterioso mundo de los núcleos atómicos y el comportamiento cuántico.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a glowing, stylized aluminium-20 nucleus at the center, emitting three radiant proton orbs that cascade outward in a dynamic, harmonious arc toward a smaller, shimmering magnesium-19 nucleus, all set against a soft cosmic backdrop of gentle blues and earthy tones, symbolizing the rare triple-proton decay and the intricate dance of nuclear transformation beyond stability.

articles.title: A natural nuclear reactor
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 22 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02138-0Questions raised by a fission chain reaction that occurred billions of years ago, and making silver compounds lighter with light, in our weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a natural nuclear reactor that existed billions of years ago, which raises interesting scientific questions and insights about natural fission processes. This contributes to scientific knowledge and understanding of natural phenomena, which is generally positive and inspiring for the scientific community and curious readers.
articles.personality_title: A natural nuclear reactor from billions of years ago sparks new scientific insights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
More than two billion years ago, a natural nuclear reactor operated deep underground on Earth. Unlike the man-made reactors we know today, this natural process was a rare and fascinating event where uranium atoms split and released energy naturally.

**What happened**
Scientists recently revisited this ancient natural reactor, uncovering new details about how nuclear fission—a process where uranium atoms break apart and release energy—occurred naturally. This helps us understand how such complex reactions can happen without human intervention.

**Impact**
Studying this natural reactor gives researchers clues about Earth's early environment and nuclear physics. It also inspires new ways to think about energy and natural processes, broadening our scientific knowledge and fueling curiosity.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to explore similar ancient sites and simulate these natural reactions in labs. This will deepen our understanding of nuclear processes and could lead to innovative ideas for safer, sustainable energy technologies.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A natural nuclear reactor from billions of years ago offers fresh insights into both Earth's history and the power of nuclear fission working naturally.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un réacteur nucléaire naturel vieux de milliards d’années suscite de nouvelles découvertes scientifiques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Il y a plus de deux milliards d’années, un réacteur nucléaire naturel fonctionnait profondément sous la surface de la Terre. Contrairement aux réacteurs fabriqués par l’homme, ce phénomène rare et fascinant remplaçait naturellement la fission de l’uranium.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les scientifiques ont récemment étudié ce réacteur naturel ancien et révélé de nouveaux détails sur la fission nucléaire — un processus où les atomes d’uranium se cassent et libèrent de l’énergie — qui s’est produit naturellement. Cela aide à comprendre comment de telles réactions complexes peuvent exister sans intervention humaine.

**Impact**
L’étude de ce réacteur naturel fournit des indices sur l’environnement ancien de la Terre et sur la physique nucléaire. Cela élargit nos connaissances scientifiques et stimule la curiosité.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs veulent explorer d’autres sites anciens similaires et reproduire ces réactions naturelles en laboratoire. Cela approfondira notre compréhension des processus nucléaires et pourra inspirer des technologies énergétiques plus sûres et durables.

**Phrase clé**
Un réacteur nucléaire naturel vieux de milliards d’années offre de nouvelles perspectives sur l’histoire de la Terre et sur la puissance de la fission nucléaire naturelle.
articles.personality_title_es: Un reactor nuclear natural de hace miles de millones de años genera nuevas ideas científicas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Hace más de dos mil millones de años, un reactor nuclear natural funcionaba en lo profundo de la Tierra. A diferencia de los reactores creados por el hombre, este proceso raro y fascinante ocurría de forma natural cuando los átomos de uranio se dividían y liberaban energía.

**Qué pasó**
Los científicos han estudiado recientemente este antiguo reactor natural, descubriendo nuevos detalles sobre cómo la fisión nuclear — el proceso donde los átomos de uranio se fragmentan y liberan energía — ocurrió de forma natural. Esto ayuda a entender cómo reacciones tan complejas pueden suceder sin intervención humana.

**Impacto**
Estudiar este reactor natural ofrece pistas sobre el ambiente temprano de la Tierra y la física nuclear. También amplía nuestro conocimiento científico y despierta curiosidad.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean explorar sitios antiguos similares y simular estas reacciones naturales en laboratorios. Esto profundizará nuestra comprensión de los procesos nucleares y podría inspirar ideas para tecnologías energéticas más seguras y sostenibles.

**Una frase clave**
Un reactor nuclear natural hace miles de millones de años nos ofrece nuevas ideas tanto sobre la historia de la Tierra como sobre el poder de la fisión nuclear natural.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing ancient underground rock formation with gentle streams of natural light filtering through, surrounded by softly colored mineral layers and subtle hints of atomic structures radiating peaceful energy, all rendered in simple, natural earth tones.

articles.title: Encouraging a ‘data sufficiency’ mindset is key for responsible research
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 22 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02318-yEncouraging a ‘data sufficiency’ mindset is key for responsible research
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: Promoting a 'data sufficiency' mindset encourages responsible research practices, which can lead to more reliable scientific outcomes and ethical standards. This contributes positively to the scientific community and society by fostering integrity and better decision-making.
articles.personality_title: Fostering a data sufficiency mindset boosts responsible research
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In scientific research, collecting and analyzing data is crucial. However, focusing on gathering just enough data to answer questions—called a 'data sufficiency' mindset—can improve how studies are done.

**What happened**
Experts highlighted the importance of encouraging this 'data sufficiency' approach in research. Instead of collecting excessive or unnecessary data, scientists are urged to focus on what is truly needed to make reliable conclusions.

**Impact**
This mindset promotes more responsible research by reducing wasted effort and resources. It also helps ensure scientific results are trustworthy and ethical, strengthening the integrity of studies and benefiting society.

**What's next step**
The scientific community aims to spread awareness of data sufficiency and build training programs. This will help researchers adopt these practices widely, leading to better decision-making and more reliable science.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Encouraging researchers to collect just the right amount of data helps create more ethical, trustworthy, and effective science.
articles.personality_title_fr: Encourager une mentalité de suffisance des données renforce la recherche responsable
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Dans la recherche scientifique, collecter et analyser des données est essentiel. Cependant, se concentrer sur la collecte juste suffisante de données pour répondre aux questions — appelée mentalité de « suffisance des données » — peut améliorer la qualité des études.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des experts ont souligné l'importance d’encourager cette approche de « suffisance des données » dans la recherche. Plutôt que de recueillir un excès de données inutiles, les scientifiques sont invités à se concentrer sur ce qui est vraiment nécessaire pour tirer des conclusions fiables.

**Impact**
Cette mentalité favorise une recherche plus responsable en réduisant le gaspillage d’efforts et de ressources. Elle aide aussi à garantir que les résultats scientifiques soient dignes de confiance et éthiques, renforçant l’intégrité des études et profitant à la société.

**Prochaine étape**
La communauté scientifique vise à diffuser cette notion de suffisance des données et à développer des formations. Cela aidera les chercheurs à adopter ces pratiques largement, pour une science plus fiable et des décisions mieux éclairées.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Encourager les chercheurs à collecter juste la bonne quantité de données contribue à une science plus éthique, fiable et efficace.
articles.personality_title_es: Fomentar una mentalidad de suficiencia de datos impulsa la investigación responsable
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En la investigación científica, recopilar y analizar datos es fundamental. Sin embargo, enfocarse en obtener solo los datos necesarios para responder preguntas —una mentalidad de “suficiencia de datos”— puede mejorar la calidad de los estudios.

**Qué pasó**
Expertos destacaron la importancia de promover este enfoque de “suficiencia de datos” en la investigación. En lugar de recolectar datos excesivos o innecesarios, se insta a los científicos a centrarse en lo que realmente se necesita para sacar conclusiones confiables.

**Impacto**
Esta mentalidad fomenta una investigación más responsable al reducir el desperdicio de esfuerzos y recursos. También ayuda a asegurar que los resultados científicos sean confiables y éticos, fortaleciendo la integridad de los estudios y beneficiando a la sociedad.

**Próximo paso**
La comunidad científica busca aumentar la conciencia sobre la suficiencia de datos y crear programas de formación. Esto ayudará a que los investigadores adopten estas prácticas ampliamente, conduciendo a una mejor toma de decisiones y una ciencia más confiable.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Alentar a los investigadores a recopilar solo la cantidad necesaria de datos ayuda a crear una ciencia más ética, confiable y efectiva.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of an open book with glowing, interconnected data points hovering above its pages like a constellation, symbolizing thoughtful analysis and careful measurement, set against a soft, neutral background with gentle light emphasizing clarity and insight.
